question:
Consider the following statements with regard to Satnami Movement of Central India.

a) The movement was founded by Ghasidas.

b) The movement was to improve the condition of leather workers.

Which of the above statements is/are correct?

SSC Stenographer 10/12/2024 (Afternoon)
option_1: (a) Only a
solution:
• Statement (a) is correct: The Satnami Movement of Central India was founded by Ghasidas in the early 19th century.
  • Statement (b) is also correct: The movement primarily aimed to improve the social and economic conditions of leather workers and other marginalized communities, challenging caste discrimination and promoting equality.
  • The Satnami movement was both a social reform movement and a religious movement emphasizing devotion to one God (Satnam).
  • Therefore, both statements (a) and (b) are correct, making option (b) the right answer.

Additional Information:

  • The movement opposed caste oppression and promoted simple living, ethical conduct, and equality.
  • It played an important role in empowering lower caste groups in Central India.

question:
Who among the following was NOT one of the founders of the Ahrar Movement in British India?

SSC Stenographer 11/12/2024 (Evening)
option_2: Maulana Abul Kalam Azad
solution:
• Maulana Abul Kalam Azad was NOT one of the founders of the Ahrar Movement in British India.
  • The Ahrar Movement was founded by leaders like Hasan Imam, Maulana Muhammad Ali, and Hakim Ajmal Khan.
  • Maulana Abul Kalam Azad was a prominent freedom fighter and scholar but was primarily associated with the Indian National Congress and not the Ahrar Movement.
  • Hence, option (b) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • The Ahrar Movement was a religious-political movement aiming to counter British colonial rule and oppose the partition of India.
  • It was active mainly among Muslims and had a strong emphasis on Islamic revivalism and nationalism.

question:
Who among the following participated in the All-World Religious Conference (Parliament of Religions) held in 1893 in Chicago?

SSC CHSL Tier II 18/11/2024
option_2: Raja Ram Mohan Roy
solution:
• Swami Vivekananda participated in the All-World Religious Conference (Parliament of Religions) held in 1893 in Chicago.
  • He represented Hinduism and delivered a powerful speech promoting religious tolerance, universal brotherhood, and the spiritual heritage of India.
  • His speeches gained worldwide recognition and significantly raised awareness about Indian philosophy and culture.
  • Therefore, option (d) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Swami Dayanand (founder of Arya Samaj) lived earlier and did not attend this event.
  • Raja Ram Mohan Roy passed away long before 1893.
  • Swami Shahjananda was a religious leader but did not attend this conference.

question:
Who founded the Prarthana Samaj in Mumbai in 1867?

SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (1st Shift)
solution:
• The Prarthana Samaj was founded in Mumbai in 1867 by Atmaram Pandurang along with other social reformers.
  • It was a socio-religious reform movement inspired by the Brahmo Samaj, aiming to promote monotheism, social reform, and eradicate caste discrimination.
  • Atmaram Pandurang played a key role in establishing this movement in western India.
  • Therefore, option (a) is correct.

Additional Information:

  • Gopal Krishna Gokhale was a later social reformer and freedom fighter associated with the Indian National Congress.
  • Shri Ram Bajpai is not historically linked to the Prarthana Samaj.
  • Ram Mohan Roy founded the Brahmo Samaj earlier, which inspired Prarthana Samaj.

question:
When was a Madrasa opened in Kolkata to promote the study of Arabic, Persian and Islamic law?

SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The Calcutta Madrasah was established by Warren Hastings in 1781 C.E.
  • Its aim was to promote the study of Arabic, Persian, Islamic law (Fiqh), and other traditional Islamic subjects.
  • This institution was intended to train Muslim judicial officers for British courts in India.
  • It is regarded as the first educational institution established by the British in India for promoting Islamic studies.
  • It later evolved into what is now known as Aliah University.

Additional Information:

  • Warren Hastings was the first Governor-General of Bengal (1773–1785).
  • The Calcutta Madrasah became a symbol of Orientalist education policy under the British East India Company.
  • This institution represented a shift in British policy to accommodate Indian religious and legal traditions in colonial administration.

question:
Which of the following social reformers of 19th century India was the author of 'Stree Purush Tulana'?

SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• ‘Stree Purush Tulana’ (A Comparison Between Women and Men) was written by Tarabai Shinde in 1882.
  • It is considered the first feminist text in modern Indian literature.
  • The book questioned the patriarchal norms and gender discrimination prevalent in society.
  • Tarabai Shinde was associated with the Satyashodhak Samaj, founded by Jyotirao Phule.
  • Her writing was a reaction to the social hypocrisy towards women, particularly in the case of a young widow accused of murder.

Additional Information:

  • Pandita Ramabai was also a reformer and wrote The High-Caste Hindu Woman, but not Stree Purush Tulana.
  • Swarnakumari Devi was a novelist and social worker, and Usha Mehta was known for her role in the Indian independence movement, especially the underground radio during Quit India Movement.
  • Tarabai’s work laid the foundation for feminist thought in India.

question:
Samata Sainik Dal was formed in 1927 by whom among the following personalities?

SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The Samata Sainik Dal (SSD) was founded by Dr. B. R. Ambedkar in 1927.
  • Its aim was to protect the rights of the oppressed castes, especially Dalits, and to promote social equality.
  • The word "Samata" means equality, and the organization functioned like a disciplined volunteer force.
  • The SSD trained volunteers to organize mass movements and maintain discipline during Ambedkar’s public programs.
  • It was an important part of Ambedkar's broader movement to uplift the Scheduled Castes and ensure social justice.

Additional Information:

  • Savitribai Phule was a pioneering woman educator and social reformer, but not associated with SSD.
  • Mahatma Gandhi formed organizations like Harijan Sevak Sangh but not SSD.
  • Narayana Guru focused on spiritual reform and caste equality in Kerala, but not through SSD.

question:
Who among the following founded the Atmiya Sabha in 1814?

SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The Atmiya Sabha was founded by Raja Rammohun Roy in 1814 in Kolkata.
  • It was a socio-religious reform society aimed at promoting rational thinking, monotheism, and opposition to idolatry.
  • The Sabha acted as a platform for intellectual discussions on religion, philosophy, and social reforms.
  • It laid the groundwork for later reform movements, especially the Brahmo Samaj, which Roy formally established in 1828.
  • The word "Atmiya" means spiritual or intellectual companionship, reflecting its emphasis on progressive discourse.

Additional Information:

  • Keshab Chandra Sen joined Brahmo Samaj later and formed Brahmo Samaj of India in 1866.
  • Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar was a reformer known for his work in education and widow remarriage, but not related to Atmiya Sabha.
  • Debendranath Tagore, father of Rabindranath Tagore, joined the Brahmo Samaj in 1842 and revitalized it, but did not found Atmiya Sabha.

question:
Which of the following Sikh reform movements was started in 1873 in Amritsar?

SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The Singh Sabha Movement was founded in 1873 in Amritsar, Punjab.
  • It aimed to reform Sikh society, counter Christian missionary and Arya Samaj influence, and revive Sikh identity.
  • The movement emphasized the purity of Sikh religion, spread of modern education, and publication of Sikh literature.
  • It led to the formation of Khalsa schools and institutions for promoting Punjabi and Gurmukhi language.
  • The Singh Sabha of Amritsar later inspired the Chief Khalsa Diwan (1902) which coordinated reform efforts on a wider scale.

Additional Information:

  • Babbar Akali Movement began in the 1920s as a radical offshoot of the Akali Movement.
  • Akali Movement (early 1920s) aimed at freeing Gurudwaras from corrupt mahants.
  • Gurudwara Reform Movement was part of the larger Akali agitation for Sikh shrine management reform.

question:
Who founded the Arya Samaj in Mumbai in 1875?

SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (1st Shift)
option_4: Raja Ram Mohan Roy
solution:
• The Arya Samaj was founded by Swami Dayanand Saraswati on 10 April 1875 in Bombay (now Mumbai).
  • It was a socio-religious reform movement aimed at reviving the Vedic way of life and opposing idol worship, caste-based discrimination, and superstition.
  • The motto of Arya Samaj is “Krinvanto Vishwam Aryam” (Make the world noble).
  • It emphasized education (especially for women), social equality, and national awakening.
  • Swami Dayanand also wrote the book Satyarth Prakash, outlining his vision for religious and social reform.

Additional Information:

  • Debendranath Tagore was associated with the Brahmo Samaj.
  • Swami Vivekananda founded the Ramakrishna Mission in 1897.
  • Raja Rammohun Roy founded the Brahmo Samaj in 1828.

question:
With reference to Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar, consider the following statements.

i) He protested child marriage and polygamy.

ii) Due to his efforts, the first Hindu Widow Remarriage Act, 1856, was introduced.

iii) He was primarily known for his scholarship in Persian language.

Which of the above statements is/are correct?

SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
option_1: (a) i, ii, iii
solution:
• Statement i – Correct: Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar strongly opposed child marriage and polygamy. He was a leading advocate for women’s rights in 19th-century India.
  • Statement ii – Correct: Due to his tireless efforts, the Hindu Widow Remarriage Act of 1856 was passed, which legalized the remarriage of Hindu widows.
  • Statement iii – Incorrect: Vidyasagar was primarily known for his scholarship in Sanskrit, not Persian. He was a renowned Sanskrit scholar, educator, and reformer.

Correct Answer:(b) i, ii

Additional Information:

  • He modernized the Bengali alphabet and contributed to Bengali prose literature.
  • His title “Vidyasagar” means “Ocean of Knowledge”.
  • He played a key role in expanding women's education in Bengal and beyond.

question:
Guru Ghasidas led which of the following movements to improve the social condition of leather workers in British India?

SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• Guru Ghasidas founded and led the Satnami Movement in the early 19th century in Chhattisgarh.
  • This movement aimed to uplift Dalits, especially leather-working communities, who faced severe caste-based discrimination.
  • He emphasized equality, truth (satya), and non-violence, and discouraged idol worship and superstitions.
  • The followers of his movement came to be known as Satnamis, and they followed a distinct socio-religious path.
  • Guru Ghasidas established the Satnam sect, which rejected the oppressive caste system and promoted moral living.

Additional Information:

  • Aravipuram Movement was led by Narayana Guru in Kerala (1888).
  • Satyashodhak Samaj was founded by Jyotirao Phule in Maharashtra (1873).
  • Nirankari Movement was a Sikh reform movement initiated by Baba Dayal Das in Punjab.

question:
Which was the first socio-religious organisation established in Bombay in 1840 to work for the annihilation of caste?

SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The Paramhans Mandali was the first socio-religious organisation established in Bombay (now Mumbai) in 1840.
  • It was founded by Dadoba Pandurang and other like-minded reformers.
  • The main objective of the Mandali was the annihilation of caste, promotion of social equality, and rational religious practices.
  • The organization criticized idol worship and emphasized monotheism and ethical living.
  • It is considered one of the earliest reformist groups that laid the groundwork for later reform movements like Satyashodhak Samaj.

Additional Information:

  • Dharma Sabha was a conservative Hindu organization founded in Calcutta in 1830, to oppose social reforms like the abolition of Sati.
  • Satyashodhak Samaj was founded later in 1873 by Jyotirao Phule in Maharashtra.
  • Vishwa Jain Sangathan is a modern organization and not related to 19th-century reform movements.

question:
Which organisation was started in the Pune district of Maharashtra in the 1870s with the aim of promoting education and social rights among the underprivileged group of the society?

SSC CHSL 11/07/2024 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The Satyashodhak Samaj was founded in 1873 in the Pune district of Maharashtra by Jyotirao Phule.
  • Its aim was to promote education, social justice, and equality for the underprivileged and backward castes, especially the Shudras and Dalits.
  • The name "Satyashodhak" means "Truth-Seekers' Society".
  • It challenged Brahmanical dominance, opposed caste hierarchy, and worked for widow remarriage, women’s education, and eradication of untouchability.
  • The Samaj functioned without any priestly class, emphasizing rational thinking and self-respect.

Additional Information:

  • Shoshit Seva Samaj was founded much later by Kanshi Ram in the 1980s.
  • Deepalaya Samaj is not historically recognized as a 19th-century reform movement.
  • Prarthana Samaj was founded in 1867 in Bombay by Atmaram Pandurang, focused on monotheism and moderate reforms, but not specifically for the lower castes.

question:
Who among the following was the pioneer of widow remarriages in Maharashtra and also started a girls' school in Poona along with his wife?

SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (1st Shift)
option_2: Gopal Hari Deshmukh Lokahitawadi
solution:
• Jyotirao Govindrao Phule was the pioneer of widow remarriage in Maharashtra during the 19th century.
  • He, along with his wife Savitribai Phule, opened the first girls' school in Poona (now Pune) in 1848, which was a revolutionary step at that time.
  • He challenged Brahmanical orthodoxy, opposed untouchability, child marriage, and promoted education for lower castes and women.
  • Phule also founded the Satyashodhak Samaj in 1873 to work for social justice and equality.
  • His work laid the foundation for modern social reform movements in Maharashtra.

Additional Information:

  • B. R. Ambedkar worked for Dalit rights and law reforms in the 20th century, much later than Phule.
  • Gopal Hari Deshmukh (Lokahitawadi) was a reformer and thinker, but not directly linked with widow remarriage initiatives.
  • Mahatma Gandhi advocated widow remarriage later, but it was Phule who pioneered it in Maharashtra.

question:
Match the following movements with their respective founders:

a. Faraizi Movement I. Sayyid Ahmad of Rae Bareli

b. Mohammedan Literary Society II. Sir Syed Ahmad Khan

c. Indian Patriotic Association III. Nawab Abdul Latif

d. Wahabi Movement IV. Haji Shariatullah

SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (1st Shift)
option_1: a - IV, b - III, c - II, d - I
option_2: a - III, b - IV, c - II, d - I
option_3: a - II, b - I, c - IV, d - III
option_4: a - I, b - II, c - III, d - IV
solution:
Let’s match each movement with its correct founder:

  • a. Faraizi Movement – IV. Haji Shariatullah

    Founded in Bengal during the 19th century, it aimed to revive Islam and reform Muslim society by eliminating un-Islamic practices.

  • b. Mohammedan Literary Society – III. Nawab Abdul Latif

    Founded in 1863 in Calcutta to promote modern education and literature among Indian Muslims.

  • c. Indian Patriotic Association – II. Sir Syed Ahmad Khan

    Established in 1888 to counter the growing influence of the Indian National Congress and to represent Muslim political interests.

  • d. Wahabi Movement – I. Sayyid Ahmad of Rae Bareli

    A puritanical Islamic movement aimed at restoring Islamic principles and resisting British rule.

Correct Match:

  • a - IV
  • b - III
  • c - II
  • d - I

Correct Answer:(a)

Additional Information:

  • The Faraizi Movement was particularly strong in rural Bengal and focused on religious purification.
  • The Wahabi Movement also had a militant edge and spread across North India.
  • Sir Syed also founded the Aligarh Movement and MAO College.
  • The Mohammedan Literary Society acted as a platform for Muslim intellectuals.

question:
Who among the following founded the Muhammedan Anglo-Oriental College in Aligarh for the spread of Western education?

SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (3rd shift)
option_1: Sir Syed Ahmed Khan
option_3: Maulana Abul Kalam Azad
solution:
• The Muhammadan Anglo-Oriental (MAO) College was founded by Sir Syed Ahmed Khan in 1875 at Aligarh, Uttar Pradesh.
  • The institution aimed to promote Western scientific education among Indian Muslims while preserving Islamic cultural identity.
  • The college later evolved into the Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) in 1920.
  • Sir Syed was a pioneer of modern education among Muslims and emphasized the need for rationalism, English education, and reconciliation with the British.
  • His efforts are collectively known as the Aligarh Movement.

Additional Information:

  • Badruddin Tyabji was one of the early Presidents of the Indian National Congress and focused more on political reform.
  • Maulana Abul Kalam Azad was a prominent freedom fighter and India's first Education Minister, but not linked to the founding of MAO College.
  • Syed Ameer Ali was a Muslim scholar and jurist, known for his work in law and for founding the Central National Muhammadan Association.

question:
Henry Louis Vivian Derozio, a teacher at Hindu College, Calcutta, in the 1820s, promoted radical ideas and encouraged his pupils to question all authority. Referred to as the _________ his students attacked tradition and custom, demanded education for women and campaigned for the freedom of thought and expression.

Matriculation Level 21/06/2024 (Shift - 1)
solution:
• Henry Louis Vivian Derozio was a radical thinker and teacher at Hindu College, Calcutta, during the 1820s.
  • He inspired his students to embrace rationalism, free thought, and social reform.
  • His group of followers came to be known as the Young Bengal Movement.
  • These students challenged orthodox Hindu traditions, promoted women's education, freedom of expression, and scientific reasoning.
  • The movement is considered one of the earliest expressions of modern liberal thought in colonial India.

Correct Answer:(d) Young Bengal Movement

Additional Information:

  • Derozio’s influence was so significant that his students were often called “Derozians.”
  • The movement laid the intellectual foundation for later reform movements like the Brahmo Samaj.
  • Though short-lived, it was important in awakening socio-political consciousness in Bengal.

question:
In which of the following years was the Self-Respect movement started in the Tamil Nadu region?

Matriculation Level 21/06/2024 (Shift - 4)
solution:
• The Self-Respect Movement was started in the year 1925 by E.V. Ramasamy, popularly known as Periyar, in the Tamil Nadu region.
  • The movement aimed to promote rational thinking, eradicate caste discrimination, and ensure social equality, especially for the non-Brahmin communities.
  • It advocated for gender equality, widow remarriage, and opposed Brahminical dominance in religious and social practices.
  • The core message of the movement was that every individual has self-worth and dignity, regardless of caste or religion.
  • It played a significant role in laying the foundation of Dravidian politics in South India.

Correct Answer:(a) 1925

Additional Information:

  • Periyar had initially joined the Indian National Congress, but left due to its Brahmin-dominated leadership and focus.
  • The Self-Respect Movement also inspired the formation of the Dravidar Kazhagam and later DMK and AIADMK political parties.
  • The movement contributed significantly to social reforms and anti-caste legislation in Tamil Nadu.

question:
Who among the following is associated with the Theosophical Society?

Higher Secondary 24/06/2024 (Shift - 2)
solution:
• Annie Besant is closely associated with the Theosophical Society, which she joined in the late 19th century and later led as its international president.
  • The Theosophical Society was originally founded in New York in 1875 by Madame H. P. Blavatsky and Colonel H. S. Olcott, and its headquarters later moved to Adyar, Madras (now Chennai), India.
  • Annie Besant arrived in India in 1893 and played a major role in spreading Theosophical ideas, combining Hindu spiritualism with Western esotericism.
  • She also became actively involved in Indian politics, supporting Home Rule, and became the first woman president of the Indian National Congress in 1917.

Correct Answer:(a) Annie Besant

Additional Information:

  • Tarabai Shinde was a feminist writer known for her work Stree Purush Tulana.
  • Sarojini Naidu was a poet, freedom fighter, and the second female President of the Indian National Congress.
  • Savitribai Phule was a pioneer of women’s education in India, especially in Maharashtra, but not linked to the Theosophical Society.

question:
Who among the following is NOT associated with the Rahnumai Mazdayasnan Sabha?

Higher Secondary 25/06/2024 (Shift - 2)
solution:
• The Rahnumai Mazdayasnan Sabha (Religious Reform Association) was founded in 1851 in Bombay (now Mumbai) by leaders of the Parsi community.
  • Its aim was to reform Zoroastrianism, promote education, and oppose outdated customs and superstitions among Parsis.
  • Key members and founders included:
    • Naoroji Furdunji
    • S.S. Bengalee
    • Dadabhai Naoroji
  • These individuals worked for religious and social reform within the Parsi community and also promoted modern education and rationalism.
  • Syed Ahmed Khan, however, was not associated with this Sabha.
    • He was a Muslim reformer and founder of the Aligarh Movement and MAO College, primarily focused on Muslim education and reform.

Correct Answer:(c) Syed Ahmed Khan

Additional Information:

  • Rahnumai Mazdayasnan Sabha is considered the first religious reform movement of modern India.
  • It laid the foundation for further Parsi contributions to Indian nationalism, especially through leaders like Dadabhai Naoroji.

question:
Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct about Prarthana Samaj?

A. Prarthana Samaj or ‘Prayer Society’ in Sanskrit, was a movement for religious and social reforms.

B. Prarthana Samaj was founded in 1863 by Dadoba Pandurang and his brother Atmaram Pandurang.

SSC CHSL Tier II 10/01/2024
option_1: Neither A nor B
option_3: Both A and B
solution:
• Statement A – Correct:

    The Prarthana Samaj (meaning Prayer Society) was indeed a movement for religious and social reforms in Maharashtra, especially Bombay (now Mumbai).

    It emphasized monotheism, morality, and reform of social evils like caste discrimination, child marriage, and lack of women's education.

  • Statement B – Incorrect:

    While Atmaram Pandurang was the key founder of Prarthana Samaj in 1867, it was not founded in 1863, and Dadoba Pandurang was not a co-founder.

    Dadoba Pandurang was associated with earlier reformist efforts like the Paramhans Mandali, but not directly with Prarthana Samaj.

Correct Answer:(b) Only A

Additional Information:

  • The Prarthana Samaj drew inspiration from Brahmo Samaj, especially after Keshab Chandra Sen’s visit to Bombay.
  • Later, Justice Mahadev Govind Ranade became a prominent leader of the Samaj.
  • It worked to bring modern education, women's rights, and social equality among Hindus.

question:
Sree Narayana Guru considered the differences based on caste and religion as meaningless and advocated the principle of ‘One Caste, one Religion and one God’ for all. He belonged to which of the following organisations?

SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Morning)
option_2: Sree Narayana Dharma Paripalana Yogam
solution:
• Sree Narayana Guru was a revered social reformer and spiritual leader from Kerala, who strongly opposed caste discrimination and religious divisions.
  • He advocated the principle of “One Caste, One Religion, One God for All”, promoting social equality and spiritual unity.
  • He was associated with and inspired the formation of the Sree Narayana Dharma Paripalana (SNDP) Yogam in 1903.
  • The SNDP Yogam was established to propagate his teachings, uplift the Ezhava community and promote education, temple entry rights, and social reform.

Correct Answer:(b) Sree Narayana Dharma Paripalana Yogam

Additional Information:

  • Veda Samaj was a reformist group based in South India but not linked with Narayana Guru.
  • Brahmo Samaj, founded by Raja Rammohun Roy, focused on monotheism and social reform, primarily in Bengal.
  • Arya Samaj, founded by Swami Dayanand Saraswati, promoted Vedic teachings and also aimed at social reform but had a different philosophical base.

question:
Who among the following pioneered the movement in the support of widow remarriage and girls’ education in Andhra region?

SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• Kandukuri Veeresalingam is widely regarded as the pioneer of social reform in the Andhra region during the 19th century.
  • He strongly advocated for widow remarriage, women’s education, and the eradication of social evils like child marriage and dowry.
  • In 1881, he established the first girls’ school in Andhra Pradesh.
  • He also founded a Widow Remarriage Association and conducted the first widow remarriage in the region in 1881, facing strong orthodox opposition.
  • Veeresalingam was deeply inspired by Raja Rammohun Roy and his reformist ideals.

Correct Answer:(a) Kandukuri Veeresalingam

Additional Information:

  • Chembeti Sridharalu Naidu was a physician and social worker but not particularly known for pioneering widow remarriage.
  • Sree Narayana Guru worked in Kerala, not Andhra, focusing on caste equality.
  • C. Rajagopalachari was a statesman and freedom fighter, active more in Tamil Nadu and national politics.

question:
Which of the following organizations was founded in Poona, Satara and other towns of Maharashtra that worked against Brahmanical orthodoxy and tried to reform Hinduism?

SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Afternoon)

The Landholders Society was founded to look after the interests of which class?

SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The Landholders Society was founded in 1838 in Calcutta (now Kolkata).
  • It represented the interests of landlords, especially those under the Permanent Settlement system.
  • The society aimed to protect property rights and influence British policy in favor of zamindars.
  • It was the first political association in modern India and a precursor to future political organizations.

Additional Information:

  • It laid the foundation for later associations like the British Indian Association (1851).
  • Though elite-focused, it marked the beginning of organized political activity in India.

question:
Who started the temple entry movement in 1927?

SSC MTS 04/09/2023 (2nd Shift)
solution:
• The Temple Entry Movement of 1927 was initiated by Dr. B. R. Ambedkar to challenge caste-based restrictions.
  • It began with the Mahad Satyagraha, where Dalits asserted their right to access public spaces, including temples and water tanks.
  • Ambedkar emphasized that social equality and dignity for Dalits were fundamental rights.
  • This movement directly questioned Brahmanical dominance and untouchability practices in Hindu society.

Additional Information:

  • The movement laid the groundwork for future temple entry laws and constitutional safeguards for Scheduled Castes.
  • It also influenced mass awakening among Dalits, inspiring further reform and mobilization efforts.

question:
Visva Bharati, a famous educational institute, was founded in 1921 by:

SSC MTS 05/09/2023 (1st Shift)
solution:
• Visva Bharati University was founded by Rabindranath Tagore in 1921 at Santiniketan, West Bengal.
  • The institution was envisioned as a place “where the world makes a home in a single nest” — promoting global cultural exchange.
  • It combined Indian traditions with Western education, encouraging creativity, freedom of thought, and unity among cultures.
  • Visva Bharati later became a central university and remains a prominent symbol of Tagore's educational philosophy.

Additional Information:

  • Tagore used the Nobel Prize money (1913) he won in Literature to help fund the university.
  • Mahatma Gandhi and Subhas Chandra Bose were among the notable visitors/supporters of the institution.

question:
Who established Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan to promote education and culture?

SSC MTS 05/09/2023 (2nd Shift)
option_1: Dr. Kanhaiyalal Maneklal Munshi
solution:
• Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan was established in 1938 by Dr. Kanhaiyalal Maneklal Munshi, a renowned lawyer, freedom fighter, and educationist.
  • Its objective was to promote Indian education, culture, and ethical values rooted in Indian traditions.
  • The institution aimed to blend modern knowledge with ancient Indian wisdom to create socially responsible citizens.
  • Today, it has numerous branches across India and abroad, offering courses in arts, science, management, and cultural studies.

Additional Information:

  • K. M. Munshi was also a close associate of Sardar Patel and served as Governor of Uttar Pradesh.
  • He was a key figure in the reconstruction of Somnath Temple and also a member of the Constituent Assembly of India.

question:
Who had founded the first Women’s University in India?

SSC MTS 05/09/2023 (3rd Shift)
solution:
• The first Women’s University in India was founded by Dhondo Keshav Karve in 1916 in Pune, Maharashtra.
  • Originally named SNDT (Shreemati Nathibai Damodar Thackersey) Women’s University, it was established with support from Mr. Thackersey, who donated funds in memory of his mother.
  • Karve’s aim was to provide higher education opportunities to Indian women, breaking traditional barriers.
  • The university played a pioneering role in promoting female literacy, empowerment, and social reform in India.

Additional Information:

  • Dhondo Keshav Karve was a social reformer and educationist who also championed widow remarriage and women’s rights.
  • In recognition of his work, he was awarded the Bharat Ratna in 1958.

question:
Who received the title Pandita from the faculty of Calcutta University for her knowledge of Sanskrit?

SSC MTS 12/09/2023 (1st Shift)
solution:
• Pandita Ramabai Sarasvati received the title “Pandita” from the faculty of Calcutta University in recognition of her exceptional knowledge of Sanskrit.
  • She was one of the earliest female scholars in colonial India and a strong advocate of women’s education and emancipation.
  • Ramabai was also known for challenging orthodox Hindu traditions, especially regarding widowhood and women’s rights.
  • She later founded the Mukti Mission to support destitute women and widows.

Additional Information:

  • Ramabai was also fluent in multiple languages and traveled to England and the USA for further study and reform work.
  • Her autobiography “The High-Caste Hindu Woman” highlighted the struggles of women in orthodox Hindu society.

question:
Who is known as the founder of the Widow Remarriage Association (1861)?

SSC CHSL 02/08/2023 (1st shift)
option_1: Dr. Atma Ram Pandurang
solution:
• The Widow Remarriage Association was founded in 1861 by Mahadev Govind Ranade, a prominent social reformer and judge from Maharashtra.
  • The association aimed to promote and legalize widow remarriage in Hindu society, which was traditionally prohibited.
  • Ranade worked tirelessly to challenge orthodox beliefs and promote social justice through peaceful and rational methods.
  • He also emphasized the importance of female education and upliftment of marginalized groups.

Additional Information:

  • Mahadev Govind Ranade was also one of the founding members of the Indian National Congress and the Prarthana Samaj.
  • He influenced many reformers including Gopal Krishna Gokhale, who later became a mentor to Mahatma Gandhi.

question:
In which language was the work of Raja Ram Mohan Roy, 'Gift to Monotheists' originally written?

SSC CHSL 03/08/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
• Raja Ram Mohan Roy wrote ‘Gift to Monotheists’ originally in Persian in 1809, with an introduction in Arabic.
  • The work was a rational critique of polytheism and idol worship, promoting monotheism as the true form of religion.
  • It reflects Roy’s early efforts to reform religious thought and promote universal spiritual values.
  • This publication laid the foundation for his later socio-religious reform movements including the Brahmo Samaj.

Additional Information:

  • Raja Ram Mohan Roy was proficient in Persian, Arabic, Sanskrit, and English.
  • He is known as the “Father of Indian Renaissance” for his contributions to modern Indian thought and reforms.

question:
Narayan Guru, a social reformer from Ezhava caste and who propagated an anti-caste movement, was born in which of the following states of India?

SSC CHSL 03/08/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• Sree Narayana Guru was born in 1856 in the village of Chempazhanthy, near Thiruvananthapuram, in the present-day state of Kerala.
  • He belonged to the Ezhava caste, a marginalized community, and worked tirelessly to eradicate caste discrimination.
  • His message of “One Caste, One Religion, One God for All” became the foundation of a powerful anti-caste and social equality movement in Kerala.
  • Narayana Guru also established temples open to all, regardless of caste, defying orthodox Hindu customs.

Additional Information:

  • He played a key role in modernizing Kerala society and promoting spiritual and social upliftment.
  • His teachings led to the formation of the Sree Narayana Dharma Paripalana (SNDP) Yogam in 1903.

question:
Who among the following founded the Indian Association along with Anand Mohan Bose?

SSC CHSL 08/08/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
• The Indian Association was founded in 1876 in Calcutta by Surendranath Banerjee along with Anand Mohan Bose.
  • It was one of the earliest political organizations in India and served as a platform for nationalist political activity before the formation of the Indian National Congress.
  • The association aimed to create political unity, spread political awareness among Indians, and demand reforms from British rule.
  • It also played a key role in opposing the Vernacular Press Act (1878) and supporting civil liberties.

Additional Information:

  • Surendranath Banerjee was also a moderate nationalist and one of the first Indian Civil Service (ICS) candidates.
  • The Indian Association later merged with the Indian National Congress in the 1880s, contributing to the broader freedom movement.

question:
Who among the following organized Sarvajanik Ganesh Utsav to inculcate national sentiments among the masses?

SSC CHSL 09/08/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• Lokmanya Bal Gangadhar Tilak organized the Sarvajanik Ganesh Utsav (Public Ganesh Festival) in 1893 in Maharashtra.
  • His objective was to use the religious festival as a tool for national awakening and to bring people together across caste and class lines.
  • It provided a public platform for political discussions, patriotic songs, and speeches under the guise of religious celebration, which helped evade British restrictions on political gatherings.
  • The festival played a key role in mobilizing the masses during the Indian freedom movement.

Additional Information:

  • Tilak was one of the pioneers of assertive nationalism and gave the slogan: "Swaraj is my birthright and I shall have it".
  • The Sarvajanik Ganesh Utsav is still widely celebrated across India, especially in Maharashtra, as a symbol of unity and cultural pride.

question:
'The Deccan Sabha' was founded by which of the following nationalists?

SSC CHSL 10/08/2023 (4th shift)
solution:
• The Deccan Sabha was founded by Gopal Krishna Gokhale, a prominent moderate nationalist and social reformer from Maharashtra.
  • The Sabha aimed to represent the interests of the people of the Deccan region, promote political awareness, and encourage constitutional reforms under British rule.
  • Gokhale used this platform to advocate for education, civil liberties, and social reform, laying the groundwork for future nationalist movements.
  • His methods were rooted in moderation, dialogue, and gradual reform, differing from more radical approaches.

Additional Information:

  • Gokhale later became a senior leader of the Indian National Congress and founded the Servants of India Society in 1905.
  • He was also a mentor to Mahatma Gandhi, who regarded him as his political guru.

question:
The Mohammedan Literary Society founded in Calcutta in 1863 was founded by:

SSC CHSL 14/08/2023 (4th shift)
solution:
• The Mohammedan Literary Society was founded in 1863 in Calcutta by Nawab Abdul Latif, a prominent Muslim educationist and reformer.
  • The society aimed to promote modern Western education among Indian Muslims, particularly in Bengal.
  • It worked to bridge the gap between traditional Islamic learning and English education, encouraging Muslims to participate in public life and government services.
  • The society also served as a platform for intellectual exchange and discussions on social and educational reforms.

Additional Information:

  • Nawab Abdul Latif was a supporter of the British education system and a pioneer in modern Muslim awakening in Bengal.
  • His efforts laid the groundwork for later reformers like Sir Syed Ahmad Khan, who started the Aligarh Movement.

question:
Rast-Goftar, a newspaper, propagated the messages of socio-religious reforms for which of the following societies?

SSC CHSL 17/08/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• Rast-Goftar (meaning “The Truth Teller”) was a newspaper started in 1851 in Bombay to promote the ideas of social and religious reform among the Parsi community.
  • It was closely associated with the Rahnumai Mazdayasnan Sabha, the first religious reform movement of the Parsis.
  • The paper aimed to counter orthodox Parsi practices, promote education, and encourage rational thinking and monotheism.
  • It was published in Gujarati and played a key role in awakening social consciousness within the Parsi community.

Additional Information:

  • Dadabhai Naoroji was one of the key figures involved in the Rast-Goftar publication.
  • The newspaper also supported reformist views on women’s rights and modern education.

question:
Who among the following devoted his life for the upliftment of widows and established the Widow Remarriage Association in 1893?

SSC CHSL 17/08/2023 (3rd shift)
solution:
• Dhondo Keshav Karve (D. K. Karve) devoted his entire life to the upliftment of widows and the promotion of women’s education.
  • In 1893, he established the Widow Remarriage Association to encourage widow remarriage, which was socially taboo at the time.
  • Karve himself married a widow, setting a powerful personal example to challenge societal norms.
  • He later founded the SNDT Women’s University in 1916, the first women’s university in India.

Additional Information:

  • D. K. Karve was awarded the Bharat Ratna in 1958 for his contributions to social reform.
  • He is remembered as a pioneer of women’s rights and empowerment in modern India.

question:
Who was the first social reformer to view modern education as a vehicle for the spread of modern ideas in the country?

SSC CGL 17/07/2023 (1st shift)
option_1: Raja Ram Mohan Roy
solution:
• Raja Ram Mohan Roy was the first major social reformer in India to recognize modern Western education—especially English education—as a key tool for spreading modern ideas and rational thinking.
  • He promoted the study of science, mathematics, philosophy, and political ideas from the West to help Indians overcome superstition and orthodoxy.
  • In 1817, he supported the establishment of the Hindu College in Calcutta and later founded the Anglo-Hindu School and Vedanta College.
  • His vision was to blend modern knowledge with India’s rich cultural heritage, laying the groundwork for the Indian Renaissance.

Additional Information:

  • Roy is also credited with founding the Brahmo Samaj in 1828, which became a powerful platform for religious and social reform.
  • He is regarded as the “Father of the Indian Renaissance” for his pioneering role in awakening India to modern values.

question:
Who among the following was the founder of the Aligarh Movement, which was largely responsible for the revival of Muslims in India?

SSC CGL 18/07/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
• Sir Sayyid Ahmad Khan was the founder of the Aligarh Movement, which played a crucial role in the revival and modernization of Muslims in 19th-century India.
  • He emphasized the importance of Western education, scientific thinking, and rationalism for the upliftment of Indian Muslims.
  • In 1875, he established the Mohammedan Anglo-Oriental (MAO) College at Aligarh, which later became Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) in 1920.
  • The movement aimed to bridge the gap between the Muslim community and British administration through education and cooperation.

Additional Information:

  • Sayyid Ahmad Khan also promoted social reform, reinterpretation of Islamic principles, and loyalty to the British as a means to gain educational and political opportunities.
  • The Aligarh Movement laid the foundation for the Muslim intellectual awakening in India.

question:
Ramakrishna Gopal Bhandarkar and Mahadev Govind Ranade carried out their work of religious reforms in Maharashtra through which of the following organisations?

SSC CGL 19/07/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
• Ramakrishna Gopal Bhandarkar and Mahadev Govind Ranade carried out their religious and social reform work in Maharashtra through the Prarthana Samaj, founded in 1867.
  • The organization aimed to promote monotheism, oppose idolatry, and work towards social equality, including women’s education and widow remarriage.
  • Prarthana Samaj was inspired by the Brahmo Samaj of Bengal but adapted its principles to the Maharashtrian context.
  • It focused on reform within Hinduism, while still respecting its spiritual core.

Additional Information:

  • Justice Ranade played a major role in organizing the Samaj’s activities and spreading its influence across western India.
  • The Samaj also worked for the upliftment of lower castes and promoted inter-caste marriage and social unity.

question:
Who among the following was one of the founders of Rahnumai Mazdayasnan Sabha or Religious Reform Association?

SSC CGL 24/07/2023 (4th shift)
solution:
• Rahnumai Mazdayasnan Sabha (also known as the Religious Reform Association) was established in 1851 in Bombay to reform Zoroastrian (Parsi) religious practices and promote social upliftment.
  • Dadabhai Naoroji was one of its founding members, along with Naoroji Furdunji and others.
  • The Sabha aimed to promote rational thinking, education, gender equality, and reform in religious customs within the Parsi community.
  • It is considered the first organized religious reform movement in modern India.

Additional Information:

  • Dadabhai Naoroji was also known as the Grand Old Man of India and became the first Indian member of the British Parliament.
  • He also played a vital role in the founding of the Indian National Congress.

question:
'Back to Vedas' was the slogan of which Reform Movement?

SSC CGL 25/07/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• The slogan "Back to the Vedas" was given by Swami Dayanand Saraswati, the founder of the Arya Samaj in 1875.
  • It emphasized a return to the original teachings of the Vedas, rejecting later Hindu customs like idol worship, caste discrimination, and superstitions.
  • The movement sought to reform Hinduism by advocating monotheism, rational thought, and social equality.
  • Arya Samaj also promoted women's education, widow remarriage, and opposition to child marriage.

Additional Information:

  • Swami Dayanand also wrote the famous work Satyarth Prakash (The Light of Truth), outlining his reformist vision.
  • Arya Samaj played a significant role in national awakening and social reform in North India.

question: Who founded the Brahmo Samaj in 1828?
option_2: Raja Ram Mohan Roy
solution:
• The Brahmo Samaj was founded in 1828 by Raja Ram Mohan Roy in Calcutta.
  • It aimed to reform Hinduism by promoting monotheism, rationalism, and social reform while rejecting idolatry, caste system, and superstition.
  • The Brahmo Samaj played a major role in modernizing Indian society, advocating women’s rights, education, and freedom of thought.
  • It became a platform for progressive Indians to debate religion, ethics, and society under colonial rule.

Additional Information:

  • Raja Ram Mohan Roy is known as the “Father of the Indian Renaissance”.
  • The Brahmo Samaj influenced later reform movements such as Prarthana Samaj and the Indian Nationalist movement.

question: The main focus of the Aligarh Movement was on:
option_3: Modern education among Muslims
option_4: Revival of Islamic orthodoxy
solution:
• The main focus of the Aligarh Movement, led by Sir Syed Ahmad Khan, was to promote modern, Western-style education among Indian Muslims.
  • It aimed to bridge the gap between the Muslim community and British administration, encouraging Muslims to adopt science, rationalism, and English education.
  • In 1875, Sir Syed founded the Mohammedan Anglo-Oriental (MAO) College at Aligarh, which later became Aligarh Muslim University (AMU).
  • The movement rejected Islamic orthodoxy and focused on educational and social reform for the upliftment of Muslims.

Additional Information:

  • The Aligarh Movement helped develop a modern Muslim intelligentsia and played a major role in the socio-political awakening of the community.
  • It laid the groundwork for later Muslim participation in national politics and educational institutions.

question: Who led the movement against the practice of Sati?
option_3: Raja Ram Mohan Roy
solution:
• The movement against the practice of Sati was led by Raja Ram Mohan Roy, one of the earliest and most prominent social reformers in India.
  • He considered Sati (the burning of widows on the funeral pyres of their husbands) as inhuman and barbaric, and fought vigorously to abolish the custom.
  • His efforts culminated in the official ban on Sati by the British Government in 1829, under Governor-General Lord William Bentinck.
  • Roy used reason, religious texts, and public petitions to demonstrate that Sati was not required by Hindu scriptures.

Additional Information:

  • Raja Ram Mohan Roy also worked for women’s rights, widow remarriage, and education.
  • He founded the Brahmo Samaj, which became a platform for various socio-religious reforms.

question: Which reformer strongly advocated widow remarriage in colonial India?
solution:
• Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar was one of the most prominent social reformers in colonial India who strongly advocated widow remarriage.
  • He used ancient Hindu scriptures to justify widow remarriage and counter orthodox opposition.
  • Due to his efforts, the Hindu Widows’ Remarriage Act was passed in 1856, legalizing the remarriage of Hindu widows.
  • He also worked extensively for female education, abolition of child marriage, and promotion of moral values in society.

Additional Information:

  • Vidyasagar was also a renowned Sanskrit scholar and educator.
  • His efforts laid the foundation for the modernization of Bengali society and inspired future reformers.

question: Arya Samaj, a reform movement, was founded with the motto:
option_1: Back to the Vedas
solution:
• The Arya Samaj was founded by Swami Dayanand Saraswati in 1875 with the motto "Back to the Vedas" (Vedo ki ore laut chalo).
  • This slogan emphasized returning to the original teachings of the Vedas, which were considered pure, rational, and free from superstitions.
  • The movement aimed to reform Hindu society by eliminating idol worship, caste-based discrimination, and ritualistic practices.
  • It promoted monotheism, moral living, women’s education, and social equality.

Additional Information:

  • Swami Dayanand also authored Satyarth Prakash, outlining his reformist ideas.
  • Arya Samaj played a major role in social upliftment, especially in North India, and contributed to the freedom struggle through its emphasis on nationalism and education.
